case_vignette:
The patient is a 46-year-old woman who presents at your primary care office for an examination with a single lesion that appears on her left arm. During the examination, it is revealed that the patient has a large sclerotic, indurated, hyperpigmented, anhidrotic, and hairless plaque on the right dorsal forearm. The patient states that these lesions had previously been slightly pink for several months before they had turned brown in color and had become “hard.” The patient has type 2 diabetes, but she has no other medical problems. In addition, she has no relevant social or family history. The patient is a nonsmoker and has no history of sun exposure. question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a single lesion on my left arm and a large hard, dark-colored, dry, and hairless plaque on my right forearm.
How long have you had these lesions?
The lesions were slightly pink for several months before they turned brown and became hard.
Do these lesions itch or hurt?
No, they do not itch or hurt.
Have you had any similar skin issues in the past?
No, I have not had similar skin issues in the past.
Do you have a history of significant sun exposure or use of tanning beds?
No, I have no history of sun exposure.
Has anyone in your family had similar skin problems or any skin cancers?
No, I have no relevant family history of similar skin problems or skin cancers.
Have you noticed any changes in the size or appearance of these lesions recently?
No, I haven't noticed any recent changes in the size or appearance of these lesions.
Have you been exposed to any chemicals or irritants that might have come into contact with your skin?
No, I have not been exposed to any chemicals or irritants that might have come into contact with my skin.
Final Diagnosis: Dermatofibroma.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient arrived reporting a distinct, singular lesion on the left arm accompanied by a larger, hard, dark-colored, dry, and hairless plaque on the right forearm. These lesions started off slightly pink and persisted for several months, eventually turning brown and hardening. The patient confirmed the lesions neither itch nor cause pain. There is no prior history of similar skin conditions, nor is there any recorded family history of skin problems or skin cancers. The patient reported no changes in the size or appearance of the lesions lately, no recent exposure to any harmful chemicals or irritants, and denied any significant history of sun exposure.
trial_0.summarized_frq: The final diagnosis is likely to be dermatofibromas.
